description: September 14, 2020: With Bulletin N. 262, the Italian Ministry of Health announced that the Italian Minister of Health, Roberto Speranza, has attended the 70th session of the WHO Regional Committee for Europe (RC70), organised by the WHO Regional Office for Europe, on September 14 and 15, 2020. Representatives of 53 countries in the WHO European Region have attended. Representatives of WHO partners such as United Nations agencies and other intergovernmental organisations and regional networks, were also present. Non-State actors (NSAs) in official relations with WHO and regional NSAs accredited by the Regional Committee, have followed the webstream and had the opportunity to submit video and written statements in advance. The key health issues and future plans have been discussed, particularly on themes regarding the response to the COVID-19 pandemic and lessons learned from the pandemic, both globally and regionally.

description: As of March 11, 2020, the Security Council in Bulgaria announced that the classes in schools and kindergartens should not be interrupted even in the areas with coronavirus cases, but strict disinfection and measures should be appllied. Students will be instructed daily about personal hygiene. Children and teachers with flu-like symptoms will not be admitted. If a coronavirus case is detected in an educational establishment, it will be closed. Student excursions are prohibited.

Exceptions to this prohibition are spelled out in the text of the order.

description:
As of May 22, 2020, the Minister of Health announced that kindergartens and nurseries would open. "Nurseries and Kindergartens remain closed until and including May 21, 2020." This is according to an order of the Minister of Health, issued today, May 19.

The mayors must create an organization for the work of nurseries and kindergartens on the territory of the respective municipalities. They must comply with both the introduced anti-epidemic measures and the instructions of the Minister of Education and Science.

description: As of May 30, 2020, the Ministry of Health in Bulgaria announced that they continued to suspend in-person attendance of classes but allowed for the following exceptions: students at all levels could access facilities to carry out activities for completion of the 2019-2020 school year and to attend training, exams and to prepare for the 2020-2021 school year when electronic completion of these activities is not possible. The institution's director is responsible for facilitating this activity in a way that complies with other anti-epidemic measures.

description: As of July 10, 2020, the Ministry of Health in Bulgaria announced that classes in the centres for support of personal development and the specialized service units of the system of preschool and school education, as well as in higher education, were suspended. The institutions shall, as far as possible, provide distance learning. Exceptions include: a) the presence of children, students and doctoral students on the territory of institutions for carrying out activities for completing the 2019/2020 school year, as well as for practical training and exams in practice and for the preparation of the 2020/2021 school year, when it is impossible to implement these activities remotely in an electronic environment and/or the actual presence is urgent. Subject to observing strict anti-epidemic measures.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

Exceptions include: a) the presence of children, students and doctoral students on the territory of institutions for carrying out activities for completing the 2019/2020 school year, as well as for practical training and exams in practice and for the preparation of the 2020/2021 school year, when it is impossible to implement these activities remotely in an electronic environment and/or the actual presence is urgent. Subject to observing strict anti-epidemic measures.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
type_sub_cat: Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
institution_status: Secondary Schools allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Full remote/distance learning (e.g. All teachers must tele-teach.)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of August 31, 2020, the Ministry of Health in Bulgaria announced that attendance classes in the preschool and school education system are resumed. The educational process is organized and conducted following the Guidelines prepared by the Ministry of Education and Science and the Ministry of Health for the operation of the preschool and school education system in the school year 2020-2021 in the conditions of COVID-19. Attendance activity in higher education is carried out according to the requirements of the respective institution, in compliance with the general anti-epidemic measures introduced in the country. The learning process is conducted remotely in an electronic environment using information and communication technologies. Language and educational centres, as well as entertainment centres organized by legal entities and individuals, provide their services in an electronic environment, and if impossible - by providing a physical distance between persons of 1.5 meters and in compliance with the anti-epidemic measures.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
institution_status: Secondary Schools allowed to open with conditions
institution_conditions: Partial remote/distance learning  (e.g. Teachers with certain health conditions can tele-teach)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As of November 12, 2020, the Ministry of Health in Bulgaria announced that high schools and middle schools close. The bulk of the restrictions introduced on October 27 remains in place unchanged. One notable modification concerns schools where previously only high schools switched to distance learning, the new guidelines require high schools and middle schools to change to distance learning if they are in districts with more than 119.9 cases of Covid-19 per 100 000 population and if at least 15 per cent of pupils were absent during the November 4-11 period due to reasons related to the appearance of Covid-19 symptoms.

description: As of November 23, 2020, the Ministry of Health in Bulgaria announced that almost all students from the Ruse district return to attend classes. Exceptions are inclusive of students from 5th to 7th grade, but only in the municipality of Ruse. They will remain in distance learning until the end of the month. The principals of all schools on the district's territory must strengthen the control over the organization and the activity in the school canteens and buffets for observance of all sanitary-hygienic and restrictive measures according to the instructions of the Minister of Health.

description: As of January 18, 2021, by order of the Minister of Health in Bulgaria, practical activities that cannot be conducted in an electronic environment will be allowed for students from 5th to 12th grade and students of higher educational institutions. A mandatory negative antigen test will be required for admission to a medical facility. It will be done in the relevant hospital and will be free of charge for every Bulgarian citizen, explained Prof. Angelov.

description:
As of January 30, 2021, amid the Covid-19 situation in Bulgaria, major universities are to begin the second semester either with online teaching or a mixed form, with students returning to in-person learning only for practical training, Bulgarian National Television reported.  
The report covered five of Bulgaria's 50 universities.  The report said that the semester at Sofia University would start at the end of February in hybrid form.  The second semester at the Medical University of Sofia begins on March 1 with education in the hybrid form.

description:
As of February 4, 2021, the Minister of Education and Science in Bulgaria announced that in addition to elementary school students, 7th, 8th and 12th grades also return to class for two weeks by order of the Minister of Health. The rest continue distance learning.

From February 18, 2021, to March 2, 2021, there will be on-site training for grades 5, 10 and 11, as well as elementary school. During this time, the remaining high school and junior high school grades - 6th, 7th, 8th, 9th and 12th grade - will be in distance learning.

From March 4, 2021, to March 17, 2021, elementary school students and students in grades 6, 9, and 12 will be in school. The rest will be taught remotely in an electronic environment.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description:
"3 years of imprisonment and a fine from 1,000 to 10,000 BGN for anyone who violates ordinances, rules and regulations or measures against the spread of infectious disease and quarantine.

Should such an act be committed during an epidemic, pandemic or declared state of emergency is related to deaths from disease, the draft amendments provides for 5 years of imprisonment and a fine of 10,000 to 50,000 BGN."  

Bulgaria. March 13, 2020.

description: Bulgarian Minister of Healthcare announced that as of 3rd Feb 2020, all arriving passengers at Sofia Airport would have to go through thermal control, as body temperature of each one is measured. At temperature above 37 degrees, the passenger is taken to an isolated room, where a questionnaire is filled and health condition is checked. People with high body temperature also pass through a separate exit. From there, they a medical team takes them to specialized hospitals.

description:
As of 00:00 on 18.03.2020, the entry into the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria will be temporarily prohibited for citizens of all States with registered COVID-19 cases.

An exception will be made for those citizens who have a permanent, long-term or continued residence in the Republic of Bulgaria, as well as the members of their families. UPDATE: At first Bulgaria just banned inbound travels from several specific countries with severe outbreaks of the Covid-19-pandemic. As of March 18, the Bulgarian Government banned inbound travels from all countries with at least one confirmed Covid-19 case.

description: As of 17 March 2020, Bulgaria's Transport Minister announced that Bulgaria will ban incoming flights from italy and Spain as part of measures to contain the spread of the coronavirus. UPDATE: Original policy only ban incoming flights from Italy and Spain. The new policy effective 18 March temporarily bans the entry on its territory of citizens from high-risk countries with corona-virus outbreaks, including China, Iran, Bangladesh, India, Maldives, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Spain, Italy, Korea, France, Germany, the Netherlands, Switzerland, Great Britain, and Northern Ireland.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Effective 20 March until 17 April 2020, Bulgaria's Health Minister issued an order temporarily prohibiting the entry of third-country nationals into Bulgaria at all border crossing points and with any means of transport, including aviation, maritime, rail and road. The ban on entry into Bulgaria of persons arriving from the following EU Member states and Schengen countries remain in force: Italy, Spain, France, Great Britain and Northern Ireland, Germany, the Netherlands and Switzerland, except Bulgarian citizens, family members of Bulgarian citizens and persons with permanent and long-term residence status on the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria. Furthermore, this prohibition does not cover: healthcare professionals, transport personnel engaged in carriage of goods, crews of aircraft engaged in commerical air transport and personnel, diplomats, government officials, humanitarian workers, third-country nationals who hold a long-term residence permit in an EU Member State and pass through Bulgaria to return to their country of residence.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Bulgaria temporarily bans the entry on its territory of citizens from high-risk countries with corona-virus outbreaks, including China, Iran, Bangladesh, India, Maldives, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Spain, Italy, Korea, France, Germany, the Netherlands, Switzerland, Great Britain, and Northern Ireland. The ban is in place as of 00:00 on March 18. Exceptions will be made for people who have permanent or long term residence permits and members of their families. UPDATE: The original entry ban into Bulgaria included China, Iran, Bangladesh, India, Maldives, Nepal, Sri Lanka, Spain, Italy, Korea, France, Germany, the Netherlands, Switzerland, Great Britain, and Northern Ireland. As of 20 March 2020, third-country nationals are added to the list, with exceptions for residence permit holders, healthcare professionals, government officials, humanitarian workers and carriage transport.

description: As of 00:00 on 18.03.2020, the entry into the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria will be temporarily prohibited for citizens of all States with registered COVID-19 cases. An exception will be made for those citizens who have permanent, long-term or continued residence in the Republic of Bulgaria, as well as the members of their families.

description: As of 25 March 2020, Bulgaria's Minister of Health issued an order that the entry into and transit through Bulgaria of heavy goods vehicles travelling to the Republic of Turkey and arriving from the following countries is temporarily suspended: Germany, Angola, Austria, Azerbaijan, Bangladesh, Belgium, United Arab Emirates, United Kingdom, Northern Ireland, Algeria, Djibouti, Chad, Czech Republic, China, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Equatorial Guinea, Morocco, Côte d'Ivoire, Philippines, Finland, France, Guatemala, Korea, Georgia, India, Netherlands, Iraq, Iran, Ireland, Spain, Sweden, Switzerland, Italy, Cameroon, Canada, Montenegro, Kazakhstan, Kenya, Colombia, Kosovo, Kuwait, Northern Macedonia, Latvia, Lebanon, Hungary, Egypt, Mongolia, Moldova, Mauritania, Nepal, Niger, Norway, Uzbekistan, Panama, Peru, Poland, Portugal, Slovenia,  Sri Lanka, Sudan, Saudi Arabia, Taiwan, Tunisia, Ukraine, Oman, Jordan. The temporary ban is effective until the explicit cancellation of the order.

description: Bulgaria's Health Minister has issued a temporary ban on the entry into Bulgaria of third-country nationals outside the EU. The new order also bans the entry via all border crossings, with any kind of transport, regardless of their nationality, of persons coming from Italy, Spain, France, Great Britain, Northern Ireland, Germany, Netherlands, Switzerland, Austria, Belgium, Iceland, Liechtenstein and Luxembourg. An exception is made for Bulgarian citizens and their families and persons with permanent, long-term or long term residence status in Bulgaria and their families. Exceptions also extend to medical professionals, transport staff engaged in cargo, foreign officials, humanitarian professionals, personnels directly involved in critical infrastructure of Bulgaria, regardless of nationality, citizens of Serbia, Turkey, Northern Macedonia, Montenegro in order to return to their countries, third country nationals who have permits in other EU countries in order to return to their country of residence.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Bulgaria's Minister of Health issued an order that as of 22 April 2020, transit through Bulgaria is only allowed in the cases when immediate departure from Bulgaria is guaranteed. Citizens of foreign countries who are allowed to transit through Bulgaria except for citizens of Serbia, Northern Macedonia and Turkey, should have previously informed the diplomatic or consular mission acrredited to Bulgaria, with assistance from Foreign Affairs.

description:
As of 24 April to 26 April 2020, a temporary ban on entry into Bulgaria of persons and vehicles coming from the Republic of Turkey through the following border checkpoints: 
a) Lesovo-Hamzabeyli border checkpoint
b) Kapitan Andreevo - Kapakule border checkpoint
c) Malko Tarnovo border checkpoint 
Exceptions will be made for cargo trucks, vehicles with special permits, automobiles transporting people who need medical treatment, as well as for vehicles performing humanitarian missions.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Bulgaria's Minister of Health announced as of 14 May to 14 June 2020, a temporary ban has been introduced for the entry into the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria of all persons, regardless of their citizenship, through all border crossings, by air, sea, rail and road transport (the ban does not apply to Bulgarian citizens, family members of Bulgarian citizens, persons with the status of permanent, long-term or long-term residence in the territory). Further exceptions apply to: medical professionals, cargo transports, foreign officials, humanitarian reasons, EU nationals involved in critical infrastructure of Bulgaria, agricultural workers, suppliers of medical products, citizens and long terms residents of EU members states & citizens of Turkey, Serbia & North Macedonia going back to their home countries.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Bulgaria's Health Minister has issued a temporary ban on the entry into Bulgaria of third-country nationals outside the EU. The new order also bans the entry via all border crossings, with any kind of transport, regardless of their nationality, of persons coming from Italy, Spain, France, Great Britain, Northern Ireland, Germany, Netherlands, Switzerland, Austria, Belgium, Iceland, Liechtenstein and Luxembourg. An exception is made for Bulgarian citizens and their families and persons with permanent, long-term or long term residence status in Bulgaria and their families. Exceptions also extend to medical professionals, transport staff engaged in cargo, foreign officials, humanitarian professionals, personnels directly involved in critical infrastructure of Bulgaria, regardless of nationality, citizens of Serbia, Turkey, Northern Macedonia, Montenegro in order to return to their countries, third country nationals who have permits in other EU countries in order to return to their country of residence. description: As of 22 May 2020, Buglaria's Heath Minister states the crew members of an aircraft flying to Bulgaria from another state can enter Bulgaria, provided that they do not leave the aircraft, except for mandatory pre-flight training, such as their stay until take-off for the next scheduled flight does not exceed their total authorized time (FDP), but not more than 12 (twelve) hours. In addition, the crew members of an aircraft flying to Bulgaria for the purpose of delivering an aircraft for maintenance and its return after that, who are foreign citizens, can enter Bulgaria, provided they do not leave the aircraft, except for the obligatory pre-flight preparation, and their time of stay until take-off for the next planned flight does not exceed their total authorized time (FDP), but not more than 12 (twelve) hours
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Buglaria's Minister of Health announced that as of 22 May, the ban on citizens of the EU, Schengen countries (including the Holy Republic of San Marino, Andorra, Monaco and Vatican City State) and UK to enter the territory of Bulgaria will be lifted. Those groups of workers that are previously excepted, the exemptions are still in placed. Exceptions for nationals from North Macedonia, Serbia, Turkey and now including Montenegro who wish to transit through Bulgaria back to their home countries are still in place. Ban on other third countries remain in place.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Bulgaria's Minister of Health announced as of 14 May to 14 June 2020, a temporary ban has been introduced for the entry into the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria of all persons, regardless of their citizenship, through all border crossings, by air, sea, rail and road transport (the ban does not apply to Bulgarian citizens, family members of Bulgarian citizens, persons with the status of permanent, long-term or long-term residence in the territory). Further exceptions apply to: medical professionals, cargo transports, foreign officials, humanitarian reasons, EU nationals involved in critical infrastructure of Bulgaria, agricultural workers, suppliers of medical products, citizens and long terms residents of EU members states & citizens of Turkey, Serbia & North Macedonia going back to their home countries. UPDATE: As of 22 May the target group of the ban is changed, the ban on citizens of EU and Schengen countries is lifted.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: As of 15 July 2020, Order no RD-01-405 by the health minister, state that those who are excluded from the ban into Bulgaria stated in the same order and who come from Sweden and Portugal, as well as from all third countries except UK, Northern Ireland, Iceland, Norway, Switzerland, Liechtenstein, San Marino, Andorra, Monaco, Vatican City, Algeria, Australia, Canada, Gerogia, Japan, Morocco, New Zealand, Rwanda, Thailand, Tunisia, Uruguay, Ukraine, are admitted to Bulgaria upon submission of a document showing negative PCR test performed up to 72 hours before entry.

description: As of 15 July 2020, Order no RD-01-405, Bulgaria's Minister of Health announce that the temporary ban on entry in Bulgaria through all border crossings no longer apply to - in addition persons in de facto cohabitation with Bulgarian citizens, persons with long-term resident status in Bulgaria and their family members, citizens of EU member states, UK, Northern Ireland, Schengen countries (including San Marino, Andorra, Monaco and Vatican City) and long-term residents in EU member states & Schengen countries - citizens of Algeria, Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, Morocco, New Zealand, Rwanda, Korea, Thailand, Tunisia, Uruguay, Ukraine. Citizens of Northern Macedonia, Turkey, Albania, Kosovo, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro will be eligible to transit through Bulgaria to go back to their countries. The ban remains for the other countries not listed.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Buglaria's Minister of Health announced that as of 22 May, the ban on citizens of the EU, Schengen countries (including the Holy Republic of San Marino, Andorra, Monaco and Vatican City State) and UK to enter the territory of Bulgaria will be lifted. Those groups of workers that are previously excepted, the exemptions are still in placed. Exceptions for nationals from North Macedonia, Serbia, Turkey and now including Montenegro who wish to transit through Bulgaria back to their home countries are still in place. Ban on other third countries remain in place. description: As of 30 July 2020, Bulgaria's Health Ministry announce that Bulgaria may permit entry for tourists coming from Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, North Macedonia, Montenegro, Moldova, Serbia, Israel and Kuwait provided that they show a negative result of Coronavirus test, not older than 72 hours. In addition, citizens of Ukraine will now be required to present a negative PCR test (in previous policy dated 15 july, they were exempted). Ban on other countries and PCR test requirement not exempted in previously stated policies remain in place.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: As of 15 July 2020, Order no RD-01-405 by the health minister, state that those who are excluded from the ban into Bulgaria stated in the same order and who come from Sweden and Portugal, as well as from all third countries except UK, Northern Ireland, Iceland, Norway, Switzerland, Liechtenstein, San Marino, Andorra, Monaco, Vatican City, Algeria, Australia, Canada, Gerogia, Japan, Morocco, New Zealand, Rwanda, Thailand, Tunisia, Uruguay, Ukraine, are admitted to Bulgaria upon submission of a document showing negative PCR test performed up to 72 hours before entry. UPDATE: In the original PCR test exemptions, Ukraine was exempted, but now as of 30 July, citizens from Ukraine need PCR test prior to entry.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: As of 15 July 2020, Order no RD-01-405, Bulgaria's Minister of Health announce that the temporary ban on entry in Bulgaria through all border crossings no longer apply to - in addition persons in de facto cohabitation with Bulgarian citizens, persons with long-term resident status in Bulgaria and their family members, citizens of EU member states, UK, Northern Ireland, Schengen countries (including San Marino, Andorra, Monaco and Vatican City) and long-term residents in EU member states & Schengen countries - citizens of Algeria, Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, Morocco, New Zealand, Rwanda, Korea, Thailand, Tunisia, Uruguay, Ukraine. Citizens of Northern Macedonia, Turkey, Albania, Kosovo, Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro will be eligible to transit through Bulgaria to go back to their countries. The ban remains for the other countries not listed. UPDATE: As of 30 July, more countries' citizens are allowed to enter Bulgaria (target group change) such as tourists coming from Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Kosovo, North Macedonia, Montenegro, Moldova, Serbia, Israel and Kuwait.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: As of 3 August 2020, Bulgaria's Health Ministry decided to allow the citizens of Ukraine and Jordan to enter without the need to take a PCR test. Bulgaria’s views regarding Ukraine, on the matter, have changed, as last week the country’s government announced that citizens coming from Ukraine must show a negative result of PCR test, from July 30. Countries that require PCR test not exempted in previously stated policies remain in place.

description:
Announced on 30 September, from 1 October to 30 November, the following countries & citizens are exempted from the ban on entry into Bulgaria through all means of border crossing: 
Member States of the EU, UK, Northern Ireland, Schengen countries (including San Marino, Andorra, Monaco, Vatican City) and their family members, citizens of Australia, Canada, Georgia, japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, Korea, Thailand, Tunisia, Uruguay, UAE, Ukraine, Northern Mcedonia, Serbia, Albania, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Moldova, Israel, Kuwait, Belarus, Turkey, persons with permenant residence in Buglaria, as well as persons holding a long-term stay visa in EU member states, UK, Northern Ireland or Schengen countries, medical professionals, transport staff, govrnment officials, humanitarian workers, representatives of economic trade, persons travelling for completion of academic training and professional athlete teams. Other countries not listed are banned.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Order RD-01-547 of 27.11.2020: In force from 1 Dec to 31 Jan 2021, a temporary ban on entry into Buglaria across all border crossings introduced. The ban does not apply to Bulgarian citizens, citizens of EU Member States, the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, Schengen countries (including San Marino, Andorra, Monaco and the Vatican City) and their family members; citizens of Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, Korea, Thailand, Tunisia, Uruguay, UAE, Ukraine, Northern Macedonia, Serbia and Albania, Bosnia & Herzegovina, Montenegro, Moldova, Israel, Kuwait, Belarus and Turkey; persons with the status of permanent, long-term or long-term residence on the territory of Bulgaria and the members of their families; persons holding a Bulgarian long-stay visa type "D", as well as persons holding a residence permit in a EU Member State, the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, or in a Schengen country (including San Marino, Andorra, Monaco and Vatican City) and members of their families. Exceptions are also allowed for certain transits.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

The prohibition does not apply to Bulgarian citizens and persons with the status of permanent, long-term or long-term residence on the territory of the Republic of Bulgaria, as well as the members of their families. Other countries banned in previous policies remain so.

description: From Jan 29 to April 30 2021, all those arriving in Bulgaria must present a negative PCR test for Covid-19, done no more than 72 hours before arriving in the country. There are exemptions from the requirement, including for drivers of international buses, drivers of international lorries, crews of vessels and aircraft, border workers and those in transit through the country.

description: From 1 Feb 2021 to Apr 30 2021 (order no.  RD-01-74), a temporary ban on entry into Bulgaria for all persons, regardless of their citizenships, through all border crossings has been introduced. The ban does not apply to: Bulgarian citizens, citizens of EU Member States, Schengen countries (including San Marino, Andorra, Monaco and Vatican City) and their family members (including persons who are in de facto coexistence with them); citizens of the UK of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, New Zealand, Rwanda, Korea, Thailand, Tunisia, Uruguay, United Arab Emirates, Ukraine, Northern Macedonia, Albania, Kosovo, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Montenegro, Moldova, Israel, Kuwait, Belarus and Turkey; persons with the status of permanent, long-term residence in Bulgaria and the members of their families; persons holding a Bulgarian long-stay visa type "D", as well as persons holding a residence permit in a Member State of EU or in a Schengen country (including San Marino, Andorra, Monaco and Vatican City) and members of their families.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Announced by the Minister of Health on 16 Feb 2021, from 17 Feb 2021, students from Greece, Turkey, Serbia, Northern Macedonia and Romania traveling daily or at least once a week to Bulgaria for training will no longer be required to provide a document proving a negative PCR test when entering the country. The same applies for Bulgarian students who live in Bulgaria when entering the country, but every day or at least once a week for training, travel to one of the five countries. PCR test requirement remains the same for all other persons arriving from countries stated in previous policy (order no. RD-01-74 / 1 Feb 2021).

description: As of May 1, 2021, the official start of Bulgaria's summer holiday season, entering the country will be possible if meeting one of three requirements: a certificate of completed vaccination against Covid-19; a negative PCR or antigen test; or a medical certificate of having had, and recovered from, Covid-19 up to six months before entering Bulgaria. The types of antigen tests that will be accepted will be listed on the website of Bulgaria's Ministry of Health.

description: As of May 1, 2021, the official start of Bulgaria's summer holiday season, entering the country will be possible if meeting one of three requirements: a certificate of completed vaccination against Covid-19; a negative PCR or antigen test; or a medical certificate of having had, and recovered from, Covid-19 up to six months before entering Bulgaria. The types of antigen tests that will be accepted will be listed on the website of Bulgaria's Ministry of Health.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
type_sub_cat: 3G: Must be either (i) vaccinated (ii) have a valid COVID-19 negative test within a certain time frame or (iii) recovered from COVID-19
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Persons arriving from India, Bangladesh, Nepal, Myanmar, Bhutan, Sri Lanka, Pakistan, Maldives, brazil, and countries and territories in Africa are temporarily prohibited from entering Bulgaria. Exceptions are the persons who are Bulgarian citizens and the persons with the status of permanent, long-term, or long-term residence on the territory of Bulgaria and the members of their families. People arriving from these places are placed under a 10-day quarantine. the order specifies countries and territories that do not fall within the scope of the ban on entry into our country.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: from 12 July mandatory electronic registration before traveling to Ireland. the digital certificate will be proof (in digital or paper format) by which the traveler indicates whether he has been vaccinated against covid-19; that he has tested negative for covid-19 or has recovered from covid-19 in the last six months. individuals who have been vaccinated in Ireland will receive a DCC from Ireland, the certificate will contain a secure QR code to verify.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Bulgaria has banned UK travelers from entering the country due to concerns about the growing number of coronavirus cases in Britain. the ban comes into force on Monday - the same day Bulgaria moves to the UK's green travel list, meaning quarantine-free travel for passengers arriving in the UK from Bulgaria. the southeast European nation has put the UK on its high-risk red zone list along with Cyprus, Spain, Fiji, and Kuwait, health minister Stoycho Katsarov confirmed. it will mean that only Bulgarian citizens, long-term residents, and their immediate family members will be eligible to enter the country from the UK.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: The village of Izgrev, Shoumen district was placed under lockdown in the evening on June 11 2020 until June 25 2020. The village will remain under lcokdown for 14 days, but also under police guard. The police will monitor the compliance with the requirement to enter or leave the village only if it is urgent, according to the order issued late this afternoon by the Regional Health Inspectorate in Shoumen. Wearing masks in the village is mandatory in indoor and outdoor public places. All markets are closed except those that sell agricultural products. Large public gatherings, including celebrations are temporarily banned.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries

description: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs recommends that Bulgarians refrain from attending public events, avoid crowded places, and comply with safety measures such as wearing a protective medical mask, maintaining personal hygiene, and avoiding direct contact with strangers. Since the PM also addressed the public on the same day and because of the previous presence of a hotline, I rate this as 2G for being the starting point of the public information campaign stage;

description: As of March 13, 2020 the Bulgarian government recommends to set-up anti-epidemic measures regarding the work environment. Foremost all employers should do everything to make home-office possible. If this isn't possible because of specific job-related characteristics, measures to decrease the danger of infection should be provided, such as disinfection, ventilation, personal hygiene awareness and reducing social contacts within the work environment to a minimum.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: The Medical Expert Council with the Bulgarian cabinet has compiled a guide on successful Bulgarian and global strategies for coping with COVID-19. description: As of 22 May 2020, the Health Minister announced that the 14-day quarantine will no longer apply to Bulgarian citizens and citizens of other EU countries who are travelling for humanitarian reasons and those who are "representatives of the trade, economic and investment activities and persons directly related to construction, maintenance, operation and ensuring the safety of the strategic and critical infrastructure of Bulgaria, implementation of projects certified under the Investment Promotion Act and persons engaged in shipbuilding and repair, certified by a letter from the Minister of Economy. Members of families of Bulgarian citizens and those who cohabit with a Bulgarian citizens are also not subjected to the quarantine when their length of stay in Bulgaria is up to 7 days. The quarantine is also lifted, regardless of their nationality, for medical specialist, workers involved in the supply of medicinal products, devices and personal protection equipment, foreign officials, frontier workers, members of armed forces. In addition, the lift applies to crew members of an aircraft which performs a flight from the Republic of Bulgaria to the territory of another country, which has not stayed on the territory of that country, except on the apron and Bulgarian citizens who are bus drivers carrying international transportation of passengers, cargo and had no contact with covid-19 cases. All other persons are subject to the 14-day quarantine.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Effective 6 April 2020: The Minister of Health of Bulgaria issued an order (RD-01-183) introducing a mandatory 14-day quarantine for all arrivals. UPDATE: The original quarantine was mandated for all arrivals in Bulgaria, now the 14-day quarantine has been lifted for Bulgarian citizens and those who cohabit with Bulgarian citizens when their length of their stay is up to 7 days, as well as for Bulgarian and other EU citizens who are travelling for humanitarian, economic and other reasons. The quarantine is also lifted, regardless of their nationality, for medical specialist, medical researchers, social workers, workers involved in the supply of medicinal products, devices and personal protection equipment, foreign officials, diplomats, officials of international organisations, frontier workers, members of armed forces and security. In addition,  crew members of an aircraft which performs a flight from the Republic of Bulgaria to the territory of another country, which has not stayed on the territory of that country, except on the apron. Lifting of quarantine also applies to Bulgarian citizens who are bus drivers carrying international transportation of passengers, cargo and had no contact with covid-19 cases. All other persons are subject to the 14-day quarantine.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: As of 22 May 2020, the Health Minister announced that the 14-day quarantine will no longer apply to Bulgarian citizens and citizens of other EU countries who are travelling for humanitarian reasons and those who are "representatives of the trade, economic and investment activities and persons directly related to construction, maintenance, operation and ensuring the safety of the strategic and critical infrastructure of Bulgaria, implementation of projects certified under the Investment Promotion Act and persons engaged in shipbuilding and repair, certified by a letter from the Minister of Economy. Members of families of Bulgarian citizens and those who cohabit with a Bulgarian citizens are also not subjected to the quarantine when their length of stay in Bulgaria is up to 7 days. The quarantine is also lifted, regardless of their nationality, for medical specialist, workers involved in the supply of medicinal products, devices and personal protection equipment, foreign officials, frontier workers, members of armed forces. In addition, the lift applies to crew members of an aircraft which performs a flight from the Republic of Bulgaria to the territory of another country, which has not stayed on the territory of that country, except on the apron and Bulgarian citizens who are bus drivers carrying international transportation of passengers, cargo and had no contact with covid-19 cases. All other persons are subject to the 14-day quarantine. UPDATE: The original quarantine stated that apart from Bulgarian citizens and those who cohabit with Bulgarian citizens as well as citizens of other EU countries travelling for humanitarian efforts, economic purposes, government officials regardless of nationality and more in Bulgaria, are subject to quarantine.  As of June 1, the geographic target has changed.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Effective 15/06/2020: Minister of Health orders (№ RD-01-334) All persons arriving in Bulgaria from Sweden, the UK, Belgium, Portugal and the Netherlands, and from all third countries except the Republic of Serbia, Bosnia and Herzegovina and Montenegro, are quarantined for a period of 14 days in the home or other accommodation. Persons who arrived from Ireland, Spain, Malta and Italy are no longer subject to quarantine, and those who arrived from 02/06/2020 have their quarantine order revoked. UPDATE: The original quarantine included the Netherlands, a new announcement effective as of 15 June stated that those arriving in Bulgaria from the Netherlands are not subjected to the 14-day quarantine. The other countries are still subjected to the quarantine.

description: The Health Minister announce on 27 March 2020 that the quarantine duration for those with confirmed cases of covid and were hospitalised due to having severe symptoms of the disease or ≥ 60 years old, regardless of the clinical course of the disease or with concomitant diseases or immunocompromising conditions, regardless of the clinical course of the disease or with the inability to isolate and treat at home, regardless of the clinical course of the disease are subject to 28 days of quarantine from the date of discharge from a medical institution. Previously quarantine only applies while they are in the medical institution. UPDATE: Minister of Health announce that as of 15 June 2020, the home isolation requirement for people discharged from hospital after being treated for Covid-19 has been cut from 28 to 14 days.

description:
Effecitive 16/07/2020: Minister of Health's order (RD-01-405/15.07.2020) that all persons arriving from the following third countries may enter Bulgaria without a 14-day quarantine: Iceland, the Kingdom of Norway, Switzerland, the Principality of Liechtenstein, the Republic of San Marino, the Principality of Andorra, the Principality of Monaco and the State of Vatican City, Algeria, Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, Morocco, New Zealand, Rwanda, the Republic of Korea, Thailand, Tunisia, the Eastern Republic of Uruguay and Ukraine. 
In the same order, persons arriving in the country from EU Member States (exceptions are Sweden and Portugal), the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, and Schengen Agreement countries are also not subject to a 14-day quarantine. 
The 14-day quarantine remains for arrivals from Sweden, Portugal and other third countries not listed here, if they do not provide on entry into Bulgaria a proof of negative PCR result within 72 hours prior to entry.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: Effective 31/08/2020: Minister of Health ordererd that the requirement for 14-day quarantine for arrivals from Turkey, Serbia and Belarus is lifted. The director of the respective regional health inspectorate shall revoke by order the issued prescriptions for qurantine of persons who arrived in Bulgaria from Turkey, Serbia and Belarus in the period from 20.08.2020 to 31.08.2020. The 14-day quarantine remains for arrivals from Sweden, Portugal and other third countries not exempted in the policy dated 16 July, if they do not provide on entry into Bulgaria a proof of negative PCR result within 72 hours prior to entry.

description:
Effecitive 16/07/2020: Minister of Health's order (RD-01-405/15.07.2020) that all persons arriving from the following third countries may enter Bulgaria without a 14-day quarantine: Iceland, the Kingdom of Norway, Switzerland, the Principality of Liechtenstein, the Republic of San Marino, the Principality of Andorra, the Principality of Monaco and the State of Vatican City, Algeria, Australia, Canada, Georgia, Japan, Morocco, New Zealand, Rwanda, the Republic of Korea, Thailand, Tunisia, the Eastern Republic of Uruguay and Ukraine. 
In the same order, persons arriving in the country from EU Member States (exceptions are Sweden and Portugal), the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland, and Schengen Agreement countries are also not subject to a 14-day quarantine. 
The 14-day quarantine remains for arrivals from Sweden, Portugal and other third countries not listed here, if they do not provide on entry into Bulgaria a proof of negative PCR result within 72 hours prior to entry. UPDATE: As of 31 August 2020, the target countries have changed to exclude Turkey, Serbia and Belarus.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Effective from 1/10/2020 to 30/11/2020: Minister of Health order (No RD-01-547) states that Bulgarian citizens and persons with permanent, long-term or continuous residence status on the territory of Bulgaria and their family members who do not present a negative PCR test conducted within 72 hours prior to entry into the country shall be quarantined for a period of 14-days in the home or other accomodation where the person has indicated that he/she will reside, with a prescription issued by the director of the relevant regional health authority. The prescription shall be revoked upon presentation of a negative PCR test conducted within 24 hours of entry into the country.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Effective from 1/10/2020 to 30/11/2020: Minister of Health order (No RD-01-547) states that if a passenger with COVID-19 is found on board an aircraft which has landed on the territory of Bulgaria, the cabin crew memebrs who severed the passenger with COVID-19 shall not be scheduled for the next flight and shall be quarantined for a period of 14 days with a prescription issued by the Director of the relevant regional health insepction or an authoritized official.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: All countries
target_who_gen: Other workers where the distinction between essential or non-essential is not explictely made (please note the occupation in the text entry)

description: Effective 31/08/2020: Minister of Health ordererd that the requirement for 14-day quarantine for arrivals from Turkey, Serbia and Belarus is lifted. The director of the respective regional health inspectorate shall revoke by order the issued prescriptions for qurantine of persons who arrived in Bulgaria from Turkey, Serbia and Belarus in the period from 20.08.2020 to 31.08.2020. The 14-day quarantine remains for arrivals from Sweden, Portugal and other third countries not exempted in the policy dated 16 July, if they do not provide on entry into Bulgaria a proof of negative PCR result within 72 hours prior to entry. UPDATE: With the announcement of a ban on entry into Bulgaria which takes into effect on 1 October, the quarantine measures for foreigners who are not a permanent resident, long-term or continuous resident in Bulgaria, arriving from all other countries no longer apply.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date

description: Effective 22/10/2020: Minister of Health, Prof. Kostadin Angelov, orders (RD-01-610) all close contact persons of a confirmed case of COVID-19 are subject to a 10-day quarantine, as of their last contact with the infected person.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)

description: Effective 20/12/2020: Minister of Health, Prof. Kostadin Angelov, orders (RD-01-719) mandatory 10-day quarantine on all persons, including Bulgarian citizens, arriving from the United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland. UPDATE: The original quarantine did not specify when the policy is due to end or is remain in place until, but as of 21 Dec 2020, the policy is announced to be remained in force till 31 Jan 2021.

description: Effective 22/12/2020: Minister of Health order (No RD-01-724) states that rapid antigen tests are added as a lab criterion in the case definition of COVID-19. Individuals with a positive antigen test will be reported as confirmed cases of covid and will be subject to 14 days of isolation, which is applied in cases confirmed by PCR tests.In this case of ill persons, the rapid antigen test should be administered within 5 days of the onset of the clinical picture.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Effective 22/12/2020: Minister of Health order (No RD-01-724) states that rapid antigen tests are added as a lab criterion in the case definition of COVID-19. Individuals with close contact with those tested positive via rapid antigen test, will be subject to 10 days of quarantine, which is applied in cases confirmed by PCR tests. In this case of contact persons, the rapid antigen test should be administered within 7 days of the last contact with a covid-infected person.

description: Effective 1/01/2021: Minister of Health (No RD-01-725) states that persons not covered by the ban on entry and stay in the country shall upon arrival present a negative PCR test carried out within 72 hours prior to entry into Bulgaria, counted from the date of the test recorded in the document. Those who do not present such test, will be subject to compulsory quarantine.

description: Effective 24/12/2020: Minister of Health order (No RD-01-725) states that persons arriving in Bulgaria by air from the UK and Northern Ireland as their point of departure wil be given a rapid antigen test at the respective airport in Bulgaria. In case of a negative result, a prescription will be issued by the Director of the relevent Regional Health to quarantine for a period of 10 days. UPDATE: The original policy mandated quarantine and PCR test for those arriving from the UK and Northern Ireland, the new policy as of 1 January 2021 states that PCR test is mandated for all countries that are not covered by the ban on entry in Bulgaria (ban lifted on 1 Dec 2020) who are also previously exempted from PCR test and quarantine. Without a PCR test, they will be subject to quarantine.

description:
Effective 29/01/2021: Minister of Health, Prof. Kostadin Angelov, orders (RD-01-50) those who do not submit a negative PCR test conducted up to 72 hours before entering the country are placed in a 10-day quarantine.
Exceptions to the requirement for a negative PCR test result are allowed for drivers of buses engaged in international transport, drivers of trucks performing or terminating international transport, crews of vessels and aircraft, border workers and transit through the country.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)
target_geog_level: All countries

description: Effective 29/01/2021 until 30/4/2021, Minister of Health (No RD-01-50) states that Bulgarian citizens and persons with permanent, long-term or continuous residence status in Bulgaria will be required to provide a proof of negative PCR test result within 72 hours of entring into the country, those who do not present the result are placed under a 10-day quarantine.

description: Effective 29/01/2021 until 30/4/2021, Minister of Health (No RD-01-50) states that Bulgarian citizens and persons with permanent, long-term or continuous residence status in Bulgaria will be required to provide a proof of negative PCR test result within 72 hours of entring into the country, those who do not present the result are placed under a 10-day quarantine. UPDATE: The original 10-day quarantine for Bulgarian citizens and persons with permanent, long-term or continuous residence in Bulgaria who did not present a negative PCR test 72 hours prior to entry, shall be lifted with effect from 2 Feb 2021 in case of a negative PCR test carried out 24 hours after arrival in Bulgaria. The quarantine is also lifted within 24 hours of submission of negative PCR result.
date_end_spec: The policy has a clear end date
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries
compliance: Mandatory (Unspecified/Implied),Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: Effective 13/03/2021: Minister of Health orders (RD-01-167)  all persons who are allowed to enter the country and who arrive from countries and territories in Africa are placed under mandatory quarantine for a period of 10 days. For these persons, the exception for cancellation of the quarantine in case of providing a negative result from a PCR test conducted up to 72 hours before entering Bulgaria is not allowed."On the 10th day a PCR test shall be undertaken, and with a negative test, quarantine shall be lifted.
date_end_spec: The policy has an unlimited time span (e.g. recommendation to wash one's hands; passing of a legal bill)

description: The Minister of Health in Bulgaria orders in the Order RD-01-354 / 22.06.2020, that enters into force on 23 June, that all sporting events may be held in front of an audience with seats up to 50% of their total capacity, when accommodating spectators at least in 1 seat or at a distance of 1.5 m. When holding football matches, an audience of up to 1000 people per sector is allowed under the conditions specified above. The rule for up to 50% occupancy of the total capacity of the seats also applies to the holding of congress-conference events, seminars, exhibitions, etc. The condition for up to 50% occupancy of the places also applies to the holding of cultural and entertainment events indoors and outdoors. This also applies to the activities of discos and nightclubs, as well as weddings, balls and other mass gatherings.

description: Bulgaria introduces mandatory wearing of masks in public from April 12 until April 26. All citizens in Bulgaria are obliged to wear a disposable or reusable face mask or another option covering the nose and mouth (including cloth, scarf, etc.) when they are in indoor or outdoor public places (including public transport, shops, parks, churches, monasteries, temples, halls, streets, bus stops, etc.). Public places are also considered to be all places which are freely accessible and/or intended for public use. This also applies to places where public services are provided.

description:
As of March 21, 2020, the Bulgarian government restricted the free entry to all parks, sport- and playgrounds and all other public indoor and outdoor places. As of April 26, the visit of parks is now allowed again for children up to 12 years accompanied by a parent or family member, but not more than two adults from 9.30 to 18.30 and for dog owners, but not more than one, until 9:30 and after 18:30
To be noted: Wearing of protective masks and keeping a distance of 2.5 meters obliged, alcohol consumption prohibited, contact with surfaces, including benches and lawns is to be avoided. This was announced by the Bulgarian Health Ministry. UPDATE: As of April 26, 2020, the visit of parks in Bulgaria is possible again under certain conditions. Originally the visit of parks was restricted without any exceptions.

Health Minister Kiril Ananiev issued an order allowing visits to outdoor shopping areas (gardens, terraces, etc.) of restaurants, fast food establishments, drinking establishments and coffee shops, subject to the following anti-epidemic measures: distance >2.5 meters between tables, staff required to clean/disinfect surfaces between visitors; make disinfectant available to visitors; Open-air terraces and gardens of restaurants will be allowed to re-open following inspections by regional health inspectorates and the Bulgarian Food Safety Agency and if all requirements for physical distancing are met, it was announced.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported

description: As of August 31, 2020, the Ministry of Health in Bulgaria announced that attendance classes in the preschool and school education system are resumed. The educational process is organized and conducted following the Guidelines prepared by the Ministry of Education and Science and the Ministry of Health for the operation of the preschool and school education system in the school year 2020-2021 in the conditions of COVID-19. Attendance activity in higher education is carried out according to the requirements of the respective institution, in compliance with the general anti-epidemic measures introduced in the country. The learning process is conducted remotely in an electronic environment using information and communication technologies. Language and educational centres, as well as entertainment centres organized by legal entities and individuals, provide their services in an electronic environment, and if impossible - by providing a physical distance between persons of 1.5 meters and in compliance with the anti-epidemic measures.
date_end_spec: The policy’s end date is unknown or unreported
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart at Secondary Schools (generally for children ages 10 to 18)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Starting March 15, 2021, In Bulgaria, the regional crisis headquarters in Kyustendil has adopted new anti-epidemic measures: Visits by outsiders to medical facilities for hospital care are prohibited, with the exception of visits to patients in the terminal stage. The prohibition does not apply to control bodies in carrying out their control activities. It is forbidden to visit outsiders in specialized institutions for the provision of social services and those for residential services for children and adults, and hospices.

target_geog_level: One or more provinces within one or more countries
